answers.author: Christal Laswell
answers.text:
Leslie
The City of Collinsville, IL is also beginning to lay the foundation for which we report performance.  We currently have a Performance Management Team that has been instrumental in developing our perfromance management system.  Much in line with Thomas' comment, we too have realized the important in keeping performance results at the forefront of the departments.  With that, our City Manager just announced to Department Heads that they will now be responsible for reporting on performance once a month as part of our Department Head or Senior Leadership Team Meetings.  They will be responsible for reporting results on key measures identified on their department's respective Balanced Scorecards.  They will be expected to provide information on actual performance and how it compares to both the previous month and the previous year's period.  In addition, action plans are required to address any undesirable trends.  Performance Management Team members will be present at this time as well to assist Department Heads in their presentation.  I have attached an example of one department's Balanced Scorecard.  The Scorecard's are regularly accessible to Performance Management Team members as well as Department Heads.  The interactive scorecard allows them to drill down and further analyze any one of the measures and provide narratives to support performance trends.
I am certainly interested in how you frame your approach and interested in any feedback anyone has to offer.
As a side note, our City Manager currently has our Leadership Team reading The Price of Government by David Osborne and Peter Hutchinson.  I haven't finished it just yet, but the theme seems to be centered upon using performance management as a method to become a results-oriented organization, holding leadership accountable to performance and so much more.  Quite honestly, I believe this book is where our City Manager is getting most of his ideas for the transition I described above.  The book provides great examples and may be a good resource if you have not read it.
Good Luck and keep us posted on your progress!!

answers.author: Meredith Roark
answers.text:
Leslie,
In Decatur, Georgia, we utilize an interdepartmental team comprised of “rising stars” (front line employees and mid-level managers) in the organization to track and collect data. This team meets monthly to discuss a number of topics including: updates on ICMA CPM, the City’s budget and review “What Works” case studies. In addition to these discussions, we highlight one service area in what is commonly referred to as a “service area spotlight.” The service area spotlight is designed to outline the general responsibilities of a department or division.  It consists of a PowerPoint presentation that highlights the Service Area Specialist’s “story” and the data they collected during the last cycle. Members of the team are quizzed on various measures for the service area, which typically sparks useful discussion about city operations and areas for improvement.

answers.author: Thomas Quist
answers.text:
Leslie,
I wholeheartedly applaud your effort to install a process in which performance data is reported and reviewed on a regular basis.  I think that this is a key component of a performance management system that will produce appreciable results.  This is what the City of Cartersville is striving towards, and to me, is the most challenging aspect of any performance management effort.
While we do not currently have a system in place to meet and review performance  measures and results, we have started reporting on select performance measures on a monthly basis.  The performance measures are included in a "dashboard report" which is distributed to all department heads, the city manager, and soon the council will receive a version as well.  While I don't feel that there is a strong coordinated review process built in at this time, the groundwork is being laid for that process.  Eventually, we hope to set goals based off of the benchmark data that we are now collecting on a monthly basis.  
The benefits that I believe this system has provided are 1) keeping performance measurement at the forefront of department's attention since they report monthly rather than annually, 2) providing detailed performance benchmarks on a monthly scale, and 3) the accountability and transparency inherent in reporting.
I'm very interested to see what strategies other jurisdictions are using to actively review departmental performance.  Thanks for posting the question!
I will attach a copy of the dashboard I referred to above.  Please note that it is intended for Excel 2007 and will not display properly on earlier versions of Excel.  Also, macros should be enabled to ensure full functionality, but they are not absolutely necessary (they are used to switch between departments using the tabs, but you can just change sheets manually if you'd prefer).  If you have any questions, feel free to e-mail me at tquist@cityofcartersville.org
Sincerely,
Tom

answers.author: [Unknown]
answers.text:
Hi Leslie,
The city of Las Vegas started a Managing for Results initiative in early 2007. We call it Performance Plus. Departments initially developed strategic business plans that divided their work into programs. Each program has a budget and performance measures. Departments revise their plans on a yearly basis. They regularly collect data, and then report out to our Performance Plus Executive Team (PPET) on a quarterly basis (even though they may be collecting data on a monthly basis). PPET consists of our city manager, 3 deputy city managers, the CFO and deputy director of Finance, and three rotating directors/upper level management. The department has 25 minutes to give their report and do a Q&A. Since time is limited, we've asked that they only focus on the measures that aren't meeting their targets. I've attached an example of the report. We are also working on Web streaming the meetings so that any city employee could watch. If an employee has comments or questions, they could ask their director.
Maggie Plaster

answers.author: Michael Baker
answers.text:
Although we're not nearly as far along on in terms of a well-integrated performance management system, I'm extremely interested in the topic and hope I can contribute to the discussion.  Here are my thoughts on how to go about establishing a process that allows for effective and regular discussion of performance data: 
- I think regular review/Q&A among an interdepartmental team or as a recurring agenda item at senior staff meetings can work very well
- I hold regular weekly meetings with each of my direct reports and could see having conversations about not only what the data means, but how to ensure that it's being appropriately considered within the organization, during those meetings
- We have a hospital in town following the health care industry's Good to Great initiative and I know that they post their performance data openly throughout their facilities in visible locations, allowing all employees and visitors to the hospital to see how they're doing   
- It might be worthwhile to convene a group of employees from across the organization (possibly community members as well) and facilitate a brainstorming session or focus group on how to best review, discuss and center attention on performance data.  They may come up with some very innovative and creative ideas and it could increase levels of engagement.  
Well, that's what I came up with.  Leslie, thanks again for starting the conversation, and to Crystal, Thomas and Maggie for sharing your examples.
Mike

answers.author: Brian Wolverton
answers.text:
In Manchester, CT, I act as the performance measurement project manager, and I work with the departments to develop and implement measures, define programs, mission statements, outcomes, etc.   All of the PM's are recorded in spreadsheets on a shared drive, which I regularly review (and sometimes audit for accuracy) and I work with departments whenever there are questions or issues.  When a department just starts with the program, we meet with the Town Manager monthly, then once they get into the swing of things, we transition to quarterly meetings.  It's a great opportunity for the Town Manager to actually see what's going on in the various departments instead of just putting out fires or focusing only on squeaky-wheel departments.  Then annually I produce a report (the first report will be released in the fall) which is available for public consumption.
We don't do anything cross-departmentally... we tried to lump together "Youth Services" in an interdepartmental fashion but just found it to be unsuccessful because folks were still in the silo mentality, so when the PD would talk about their programs, the human services folks would zone out, and vice versa.  So at this point we're just being pragmatic and focusing on gathering, discussing, and reporting data.  Hopefully as the program evolves something more integrated will come of it.
Here is our preliminary report:
http://www.townofmanchester.org/Budget/Documents/June2009PMStatusReport.pdf
http://www.townofmanchester.org/Budget/Documents/November2008PMStatusReport.pdf

answers.author: Kathryn Gregory
answers.text:
Leslie, 
The City of Peoria is also developing a "CompStat" like program.  Performance Measurement has slowly but progressively been inculcated into the organization over the years.  This past year we have focused on a more strategic approach to developing our budget.  This included finalizing an Organizational Strategic Plan, having all departments complete a Strategic Operating Plans and we also completed a Citizen Survey and an Employee Survey.  
Armed with all this, we are now in the position to start truly USING the data we have been collecting in a more meaningful way, so I think we are at a similar point in the process.  Our approach is going to be similar to what Louise referred to regarding the City Of Mesa, however every organization has it's nuances, so we are going to remain open and flexible as we develop our process design. 
I am currently working with departments to identify appropriate outcomes and measures by which their performance will be judged, and as I am sure you have experienced, it can be difficult as best.  The plan is to collect data  monthly, and report quarterly...  I was directed to some process design information from King County, Washington  at http://www.kingcounty.gov/exec/strategy/PerformMgmt/KingStat.aspx
They have a guidance document that outlines their "Stat" program.  It also includes a description of the types of measures to consider, how to put together presentation and provides good references at the end of the document.  Maybe it will help get the creative juices flowing... 
In any event, thanks for posting the question and please continue to share your progress. 
Katie Gregory

We started fairly simple and have built on it for a few  years. For low cost and easy buy-in we use annual measures only in our reporting program, but they all roll up to outcomes and make pretty good sense at the community level.  Our reporting is by department (good ownership) but rolled up at City level in Strategic Indicators. We just published our 2009 report here: http://www.cityofvancouver.us/upload/contents/582/2010%20City%20of%20Vancouver%20Performance%20Report.pdf
Tom
